name: Consul 2717
keyboard: Typewriter type. 79 keys with editing keys and 11 function keys
size: Display: 30 (W) x 27 (D) x 30 (H) / 8 kgKeyboard: 49 (W) x 22.6 (D) x 4.5 (H) cm / 2 kg
ports: Keyboard, Tape recorder, 2 x expansion connectors
power: Built-in power supply unit - 220V - 42 to 68 Hz
description:
ZBA is the abbreviation of Zbrojovka Brno. Brno being the Czech city the company was located in. 

The Consul 2717 was a clone of the Tesla PMD 85.2 but had a very different design. The mainboard was located in the display case and the keyboard had a more professional look. 

The machine was only sold to Czech schools. In its basic version it was used with the built-in BASIC-G interpreter which had some graphic commands. Programs could be stored through an external tape recorder. 

However, thanks to its dual expansion connectors, the 2717 could be connected to an external floppy drive unit and run the CP/M operating system, or to a network. The system could also boot from an external ROM chip. 

The machine was entirely built with East European components coming mainly from Tesla, but also from Russia. It had a short life, it was manufactured for less than one year.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Note the two expansion connectors next to the keyboard plug.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The inside electronics is composed of three cards:<br> • Power supply card, on the left side,<br> • Video card on the right side,<br> • logic card at the back, with a metallic protection against magnetic shields.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> 8228 bus controller<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> MHB 8080A processor, Tesla version<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> 64 KB RAM chips<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> I/O chips. From left to right:<br>   - MHB 8251 (TESLA version of USART i8251)<br>   - KR580VI53 (Russian version of PIT i8253)<br>   - MHB 8255A (TESLA version of PIO i8255A)<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Keyboard connector<br> <b><font color="blue">(6)</font></b> Dual expansion connectors<br> <b><font color="blue">(7)</font></b> Tape recorder DIN socket<br> <b><font color="blue">(8)</font></b> BASIC-G Russian ROM chips. </blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert said : <br><br> Waiting for you, all the incredible performance and power of the IMSAI 8080. And at a price you would normally pay for a home music system : $699 in kit, $931 assembled...<br><br> <b>WORLS OF USES : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is a superbly engineered, putting litterally hundreds of applications and uses at your fingertype...<br><br> <b>GROWS WITH YOU : </b>The IMSAI 8080 is designed for many years of pleasure. With its open-chassis engineering, you can expand your system by adding peripherals and interfaces. The 22 slots and 28 amperes power supply mean that you can plug-in todays's plus tomorrow's modules. Right now, you can add a module for displaying color graphics and characters on TV, a ready-to-use keyboard, a cassette tape recorder, small and large printers...<br><br> <b>EASY TO PROGRAM : </b>With our BASIC language, you can operate the IMSAI 8080 quickly and easily. Thechnically knowledgeable ? Use our assembly language to develop sophisticated and unique software.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST US AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SORD BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Tim Mackay</b> </p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT MARCH 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, March 1982 issue.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for correspondance courses using MPF-1 computers.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>English advert for the 86A model.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN LEAFLET #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"This flexibly expandable computer grows by the increase of business activities and the rising requirements."<br><br> A reliable office computer, which can flexibly adapt to the business work, as it is essential for the office to execute resulting works promptly, correctly, and precisely.<br> A user-friendly conceived EDP-system like the MZ-3541 is essential, particularly for small to medium sized companies.<br> The MZ-3541 contributes for a substantial increase of the productivity in the office by the assumption of routine works. SHARP has designed the new MZ-3541 in such a way that it can be used for the most diverse resulting office works. And because multiple peripheral devices are available, the system can grow dynamically with the business activities.<br><br> The MZ-3541 is the result of Sharp's extensive market study and ergonomics studies. The free mobile keyboard makes data input and the operation easier and allows for spatial conditions an adapted installation of the system possible.<br> Sharp's MZ-3541 - the complete system for the business data processing.      <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future....  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GENEVA AD, OCT. 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>We can see here the Palcom PX-7 with all its Pioneer extensions : the graphic tablet, the Laser Disc player, a joystick and even the TV is a Pioneer !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #3 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this advert, Victor tried to convince future IBM PC buyers that the Victor 9000 hardware technology was much more advanced than that of its competitor. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br> No waiting for software<font color="#666666"> ...This exciting micro has fired the imagination of programmers who are busy developping new software to take full advantage of its performance capabilities...</font><br><br> No wait state<font color="#666666"> ...One advantage is the total elimination of memory access wait states so that interaction between the processor, RAM and disk drive is speeded up...</font><br><br> A free p-System for those who don't wait <font color="#666666"> ...A free p-System operating system and PASCAL, FORTRAN 77 and BASIC compilers which alone lists for $1475, we're now including free with the Sage II...</font>  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-1200 (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The industry said it couldn't be done. You can't put a hard disk in a portable PC, make it powerful and keep it under 11 lbs.<br> Well, with this that challenge in mind, we immediately went to work to prove them wrong, presenting the result, the new T1200... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IIE VERSION</strong></font><br><blockquote>Promotional picture. Notice the dual floppy drive module on top of the case, inspired by the Franklin <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/museum/computer.asp?st=1&c=646" target="_blank">ACE 1200</a><p class="petitgris">Roberto Isiri</p></blockquote>
